data.text: Two-Person Camping Tents: Any Advice?
Hello there. What tent for 2 people (+equipment) do you have for long cycling trips? Thank you for yours recommendations! Edit: thank you very much for all tips!!!
MSR Hubba Hubba
data.author: Sol Findley

data.text: I have used many over the years. This year, on my 3200km camping trip, i am going to use a tipi ( one tigris Smokey hut) . It will sleep 4 people but, with a half size mesh inner, i have room to put the bike in the tent too. I was going to take my Lanshan tent that is under 1kg but i willuse that for shorter trips. The smokey hut weighs in at 2kg which is comparable to many one man tents on the market but, gives me loads of flexibility. I may also carry a small tarp for some discreet wild camping .
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: thanks for your tip. It is quite a good idea!
data.author: Katja Sz

data.text: I use an MSR Elixr 2 similar to the Hubba Hubba slightly heavier but more stable.
data.author: Alan Ferrier

data.text: i was thinking of it. Is there enough place for 2 people?
data.author: Katja Sz

data.text: think so but I'm usually traveling solo. It has a door on both sides so you don't have to climb over one another to get out.
data.author: Alan Ferrier

data.text: thanks!
data.author: Katja Sz

data.text: - I also use Elixir 2 for two people. It is more robust than Hubba and comes with a footprint, so there is an option of ‚Äûlight setup‚Äù - the footprint and rainfly, w/o the inner part (I‚Äôve never done that, though). The weight is not an issue, especially if you split the package between two cyclists, however I am considering buying a 1-person Hubba for solo travels, mainly to save kilograms as well as some volume. Two people sleep comfortably inside Elixir 2, but the luggage must stay in vestibules.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: We use a super light Z tent free trio tent works well for being under 1kg. Suits 2 people than 3 can pack gear inside if needed.
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: My latest tent is MSR mutha, is meant for 3 but I use it for 2 and you can sleep in Jesus christus position in that roomy 2 kilos tent
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: thanks! I will look at it
data.author: Katja Sz

data.text: - but it seems that Mutha Hubba is just 3-person model in the Hubba series, isn‚Äôt it?
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: it shares the name Hubba but is totally other design. The Mutha shape is half pipe and the entrance is at both ends of the pipe (smaller doors than others with entrance at the side, its a compromise cos is only 2 kilos, as big inside as it can be, self standing but not as stable as igloo-dome crossed poles tents, it doesn`t stink like a cheap plastic, the outter tent material is extremely thin and light. i use a foot print to protect the thin floor. I would buy it again . For careless use or super windy regions i have the denali IV from salewa which beats the mutha in every department but not as light. (the mutha for short trips is my first choice).
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: Salewa micra II ist strong, inexpensive, great quality , under 2.4 kilos but 2 persons fit there only sleeping in a spring roll position. however for one person is perfect.

data.text: Depends on which region‚Ä¶. Wind? Temperature, sand storms? Snow? I would go for a 3 people one, two entrances with vestibules. And vestibules with good aeration that still ventilate while raining. I like the Vaude ones, for example Mark 3P.

data.text: MSR Hubba - really like it. Doesn‚Äôt leak even in torrential downpours. Did get water on the floor once but that was my fault with poor positioning and no drainage ditch. Once I figured that out I stayed nice and dry when everything around was flowing!
data.author: John Goldman

data.text:
I use Terra Nova. Their Wild Country range isn't too expensive, and still very high quality materials. Personally I like a two person tent when travelling alone to store gear, and most importantly to be able to sit up in the porch and cook if I need to. https://www.terra-nova.co.uk/products/trisar-2/
Trisar 2
terra-nova.co.uk

data.text:
If there's two of you travelling together you might to want to consider the larger model: https://www.terra-nova.co.uk/products/trisar-2d/
Trisar 2D
terra-nova.co.uk
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Sea2summit have about a year or more ago launched a range of tents that get really good reviews - some prefer to the msr or copper spur
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: If for 2 people then I agree with comments about getting a three person tent. Personally I would get a free standing tent, unless you know you will always be pitching on soft ground. I would also look at the internal height of the tent, as a taller tent will allow you to sit up, and it will also give you more space above your feet and head when you lie down, because the end slopes are steeper. Some tents have a separate spreader bar in the middle of tent. This pushes out the walls and makes them more vertical, this will give you a lot more elbow room, especially if there are two of you. Look for tents with two entrances. Side entry is easier, and it allows each of you to get out of the tent for a pee at night, without having to climb over the other person. Often these tents will have two vestibules, which is great for storage or cooking in the rain. Most of the common tents have reviews on Youtube, which could save some regrets later.
data.author: Mark Perry
Per-Erik Sleipner

data.text: i have just Googled it. It seems to be great, but this price...
data.author: Katja Sz

data.text: Also a nightmare in warmer weather, and it is not free standing. And free standing is a must for hassle-free versatility. A cheap tent could last long against all odds. And expensive one can break after a week or in the first storm. Personal experience and that from other multiple-long-distance tourers. Aka over a year on the road mostly camping.
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: We bought a Hilleberg Staika. It cost almost ¬£1000, we thought we were investing. Mistake, they are good for tunnel tents, but this design ain't great. We'll have to stick with the drippy outer that falls into your tent just because a thousand quid is a thousand quid, but ...... Wouldn't buy again. Having said that, we've always felt super safe, sturdy and weatherproof in our Hilleberg, it's the design that needs a tweak üòç
data.author: Lynne Sixtyodd Roberts

data.text: Big Agnus.3 person tent. Lots of room for kit and 6'4 hubby can lay down. Unfortunately after a visitation from a cat, domestic not wild, it is no longer fully midge proof. üôÄüòÇ
